channel.title: SFGate: Business & Technology
channel.description: Business and technology news. From SFGate.com: the Bay Area's home page, online home of the San Francisco Chronicle and much more.
channel.feedburner:browserFriendly: This is an RSS feed, but with the headlines made visible. Choose one of the buttons to add this feed to your favorite RSS reader.

item.title: Stocks Continue Slide Despite GDP Report
item.description: Wall Street extended its steep decline Friday, propelling the Dow Jones industrials down more than 500 points over two days after investors gave in to mounting concerns that borrowing costs would climb for both companies and homeowners. It was the Dow's worst...
item.author: By TIM PARADIS, AP Business Writer

item.title: Ex-Qwest Boss Gets Six Years in Prison
item.description: Former Qwest Communications chief executive Joe Nacchio got six years in prison and was ordered to give up all his ill-gotten gains on Friday for hiding his company's problems from investors even as he dumped shares at a huge profit. U.S. District...
item.author: By SANDY SHORE, AP Business Writer

item.title: Chevron's 2Q Profit Soars 24 Percent
item.description: Chevron Corp.'s profits surged to a new high during the second quarter as the nation's second largest oil company cashed in on higher gasoline prices and cashed out of a major investment. The San Ramon-based company said Friday that it earned $5.38...
item.author: By MICHAEL LIEDTKE, AP Business Writer

item.title: EU charges Intel with monopoly abuse
item.description: EU regulators said Friday they have charged Intel Corp. with monopoly abuse for customer rebates and below-cost pricing that undercut rival computer chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. Intel immediately said its conduct had been lawful, good for...
item.author: By AOIFE WHITE, AP Business Writer

item.title: DAILY DIGEST
item.description: Chain consolidates newsroom operations The Oakland Tribune, Contra Costa Times and several other East Bay newspapers plan to combine their news operations, according to an e-mail sent to employees by John Armstrong, publisher of the Contra Costa Times.<...
item.author: Verne Kopytoff

item.title: TECH CHRONICLES
item.description: Socialization of personalization Dan Cohen has worked on the personal home pages at two of the biggest Internet firms, helping build MyYahoo and iGoogle. Now he's running a San Francisco startup, Pageflakes, that is taking that concept into the social-...
item.author: Dan Fost, Ellen Lee

item.title: Where is the media watchdog?
item.description: This is my last column for The Chronicle. And, no, I haven't been fired. More on that in a moment. First, I want to take this opportunity to look at the state of consumer advocacy in the United States. And who better to turn to than Ralph Nader, the...
item.author: David Lazarus

item.title: Record $3 million fine for Kaiser
item.description: Kaiser Permanente must pay a record $3 million fine after state investigators found that the health maintenance organization, the country's largest, did not adequately track patient complaints about treatment. The penalty, announced Thursday, marks the...
item.author: David R. Baker

item.title: Assistance for foreign speakers
item.description: State utilities regulators voted Thursday to require telecom carriers that market in a foreign language to also provide support to customers in that language. The Public Utilities Commission is the first state regulatory body to require such rules,...
item.author: Ryan Kim

item.title: Chevron reports largest quarterly profit ever of $5.38 billion
item.description: Chevron Corp. on Friday reported its largest quarterly profit ever, $5.38 billion, the result of high oil and gas prices this spring. That's 24 percent more money than Chevron made in the same quarter last year and easily beats the company's previous...
item.author: David R. Baker

item.title: Real estate portals squabble over content / Trulia boots upstart Terabitz out of its space
item.description: A new real estate portal founded by a Silicon Valley veteran and his teenage son has had to decouple its site from another Bay Area Web firm over concerns about how home listing information was being used. The scuffle between the two Web firms - in the...
item.author: Kelly Zito

item.title: Facebook founder under fire
item.description: Facebook, one of the hottest social-networking sites on the Internet, landed in a Boston courthouse Wednesday facing charges that its founder stole the idea for the company from a competing site. ConnectU, a much smaller social network in Connecticut,...
item.author: Dan Fost

item.title: FDA eyes nanotech standards
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration needs to beef up its expertise in the field of nanotechnology to ensure the safety of the coming wave of products it will have to regulate, an agency task force said in a report issued Wednesday. Cosmetics, food,...
item.author: Bernadette Tansey

item.title: Circuit breakers wipe out the Web / PG&Es faulty equipment reveals the Internets vulnerability to a disruption of its power source
item.description: All it took to wipe out some of the Internet's biggest sites Tuesday was some faulty PG&E electrical breakers that caused a blackout in downtown San Francisco. Some of the Web's hottest destinations - Craigslist, Yelp, Second Life - were suddenly...
item.author: Verne Kopytoff

item.title: APPLE POLISHES ITS QUARTERLY PROFIT / Jobs: 1 million iPhones sold by September
item.description: Despite early indications that Apple's iPhone had a disappointing introduction, the company's latest financial figures reveal a solid release and a promising future. In the two days the iPhone was on the shelves before the quarter ended - June 29 and...
item.author: Ellen Lee

item.description: Offering the first glimpse at whether the iPhone lived up to its hype, AT&T said Tuesday that it activated 146,000 iPhones during the first two days of its premiere, far less than some of the loftier sales estimates. The news sent shares of Apple Inc.,...

item.title: TiVo gearing up for HD fight
item.description: It's no secret that TiVo, the groundbreaking digital video company that caught many people's hearts and eyeballs since its inception in 1997, has struggled to maintain market share in recent years due to increased competition from cable and satellite...
item.author: Ellen Lee

item.title: Microsoft and Ask.com pushing for more privacy
item.description: Microsoft Corp. and Ask.com called on the technology industry to craft safeguards to better protect consumer privacy, answering a growing chorus of criticism about the amount of data Internet companies collect about their users. The project, proposed...
item.author: Verne Kopytoff

item.title: Andreessen strikes gold again with Opsware sale
item.description: Marc Andreessen has done it again. Many credit the Internet wunderkind with launching the go-go years in Silicon Valley when his software company, Netscape Communications, had a stratospheric public stock offering in 1995. Now 36, the second company...
item.author: Dan Fost

item.title: HDTV via antenna won't get all channels
item.description: Q: I'm thinking of getting a high-definition television. I have cable, but I'm not keen on paying extra for HDTV programming. I've heard that it's possible to receive HDTV signals over the air using an antenna. Is this true? A: It is, but read...
item.author: David Einstein

item.title: Teen's social-networking site a hit with high schoolers / MyYearbook battles it out with Facebook, MySpace to be the online place to meet
item.description: Not many teenagers raise $4.1 million in funding at the same time they're learning how to drive. Or attend a business meeting the morning before their senior prom. Or appear on CNBC and then return to school to take a calculus test. This is the life...
item.author: Ellen Lee

item.title: ANALYSIS / Credibility called into question / Will SunRocket's failure jeopardize Net phone firms?
item.description: Internet telephone provider SunRocket's sudden closure last week not only surprised and disappointed subscribers, it also cast a shadow on the future of similar, low-cost Internet phone services. SunRocket, with more than 200,000 subscribers, was the...
item.author: Ryan Kim

item.title: PLUG-IN HYBRIDS / Making green cars greener costs a bundle / With $24,000 add-on, plug-in Toyota Prius is mostly for rich
item.description: Want to be the first on your block with a $50,000 Toyota Prius? Head to Hybrids Plus in Boulder, Colo., and leave your Prius with their technicians. Go skiing or something, come back in three or four days with a check for $24,000 and you will have one...
item.author: Michael Taylor
